Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project: RISE - Research-based Interdisciplinary STEM Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborators at North Seattle Community College (NSCC) and Central Washington University are developing a model for institutionalizing an interdisciplinary and research-based curriculum. The project goals are to (a) provide progressive and innovative STEM curriculum that significantly improves preparation of diverse student populations for upper level courses and careers in science, (b) establish the foundation for a Pacific Northwest Collaboration focused on excellence in STEM education at the community college level, and (c) make a significant contribution to the body of knowledge regarding our understanding of how students think, learn, and problem solve in a research and interdisciplinary context early in their college experience.

The "thinking is valued" framework, in which developing thinking dispositions within and across disciplines is seen as the key to academic success, is embedded in the curricular changes envisioned. The collaborators will use undergraduate research and interdisciplinary experiences as vehicles to cultivate meaningful thinking opportunities in the first and second years of the college experience. Formative and summative evaluation will address three questions (a) Does the project provide evidence of new "habits of thinking" from students and faculty who participate in the interdisciplinary and research-based STEM curricula? (b) Does interdisciplinary and research-based curriculum enhance teaching practices and student learning outcomes? and (c) Is the project reaching other community colleges and universities? A combination of faculty/administrator review panels, student classroom assessment, student/faculty/staff interviews, and institutional presentations will be used to document, analyze, and update project findings. Dissemination of new materials and results will impact a wide range of educators through direct partnerships with practicing faculty, a web presence that serves to distribute curriculum, and presentations at national meetings throughout the duration of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Research-based Interdisciplinary Science Education (RISE) project was a novel regional collaboration that created a model for institutionalizing interdisciplinary and research-based curriculum for introductory chemistry and biology courses. By centering this collaborative effort at North Seattle College (NSC), the RISE project addressed the need to embed research experiences early in the post-secondary curriculum, increase engagement of underrepresented students in STEM career pathways, and deeply engage students in developing 21st century skills and thinking dispositions. North Seattle College and Central Washington University (CWU) faculty collaborated to develop and implement high-impact STEM learning experiences for community college students as a means to better prepare them to be successful in the increasingly challenging STEM pipeline and rapidly evolving global job market.

Specifically, the RISE project:

A) provided progressive and innovative STEM curriculum that significantly improved preparation of diverse student populations for upper level courses and careers in science

B) made a significant contribution to the body of knowledge regarding our understanding of how students think, learn, and problem solve in a research and interdisciplinary context early in the college experience.

The project goals were achieved through four objectives:

Objective 1:  Transform introductory chemistry and biology series for STEM students to be both interdisciplinary and research-based

Objective 2:  Design and implement a sustainable undergraduate research program for 2nd-year students

Objective 3:  Gain a better understanding of the student learning and thinking processes that occur as a result of engaging with interdisciplinary and research-based curricular modules in first and second year STEM courses

Objective 4: Widely disseminate RISE project curriculum, results, and transformative approach to designing introductory science courses

Over its five-year implementation, the RISE project developed, refined, and assessed eight unique curricular modules, called Interdisciplinary Investigations (IDIs) for use in general chemistry and general biology courses. The modules connect students to current problems such as global water supply, extend their thinking across disciplinary boundaries and into primary literature, and challenge students to work collaboratively to develop models to explain complex phenomenon using threshold concepts from multiple disciplines.

This classroom work was supported by complimentary curriculum for the laboratory developed with the help of an expert research chemist. The RISE project brought a four-year university scientific research platform to a two-year college context through the iterative design of investigative laboratory curriculum that centers on some of the most pressing environmental challenges facing the world today. Essential design components were (i) hands-on exposure to sophisticated instrumentation in association with (ii) activities and experiences that establish a culture of thinking where student voices are encouraged, valued, and driven by engagement with relevant issues.

Across the life of the grant, the RISE project trained ten faculty and implemented the curriculum in both classroom and laboratory settings for well over 1000 students. Assessment of the student outcomes revealed substantial gains in students' self-efficacy as well as mastery of critical content such as intermolecular forces at levels well above the national average.

In addition to the curriculum for these gateway STEM courses, the RISE project refined and assessed curriculum for a year-long undergraduate research program for early STEM students. Early research experiences are a widely recognized, high-impact practice that can support and retain under-represented students in STEM. The curriculum developed through the RISE project focuses on using authentic research as a powerful tool to help students develop into competent, creative researchers and scholars. It emphasizes both hard skills (instrumentation, lab notebooks, data analysis, etc.) as well as an array of soft skills (small group communication, building a professional network, crafting an effective CV) to improve student performance and retention. The program is collaborative by design, providing rich opportunities for students to build community and STEM identity as they progress through the program. Across the life of the grant, over 100 students conducted authentic research as part of five cohorts in the program.

In addition to these direct benefits to faculty and students, the RISE project also served as a catalyst and stepping-stone for community transformation at North Seattle College. The biology program at NSC, for example, leveraged external funds to obtain a research-grade instrument that could be used to design authentic research experiences for biology courses using the RISE model. Faculty interest in developing more active, collaborative curriculum for the classroom was leveraged to obtain external funding to transform a conventional classroom into an active learning center that better supports the pedagogy of the new curriculum. The RISE project has also inspired the college to seek additional funds to support underrepresented students in STEM and ensure that all students have rich opportunities to reach their full potential using engaging, interdisciplinary, evidence-based curriculum in both classroom and laboratory environment.
